text:
Hey all! Super curious how other Content Leads handle the creation/ideation of their editorial calendars.

This is probably totally dependent on factors like size of the team, resources, team expertise, etc. but I'm curious: how much of a role do the individual contributors (writers) on your teams have in creating the editorial calendar vs. the lead?

I've typically experienced the lead handling the majority of the editorial calendar setting to start, then as the team members gain more experience, they start owning their own section of the calendar.

Would love to know how others do it!

text: Following — editorial cals are fascinating because I find they depend so much on the company, team, and type of content marketing

elements.text: Following — editorial cals are fascinating because I find they depend so much on the company, team, and type of content marketing

text: Totally, <@UJ7RT1J1X>! How does your team do it?

elements.text: ! How does your team do it?

text:
Content lead for an SEO agency here. I’m probably an outlier, but here goes.

*Content team size*: 2. No writers on staff.
*Freelancer roster*: ~30 — a mix of hired guns, on-demand writers, and a few we have on retainer-type contracts for ongoing work.

Short answer: We come up with the strategy based on target keywords/topics. We create, control, and execute the calendar. Writers don’t.

Our content team creates the editorial calendars. Based on keywords we want to target for our clients, we come up with X blogs/FAQs/other stuff per month. Usually plan out topics for 3-4 months max.

Beyond that, we start seeing how pages perform and sometimes refresh/update them. It’s a bit of a fool’s errand IMO to plan out more than that, unless we’ve identified topics that clients _know_ they want to publish down the road. Like seasonal topics, for example. It varies.

As an SEO agency, we’re instant experts in all sorts of topics, but we usually have an SME on the client side to tap as needed. I try to align our freelance writers to the same clients so they’re more familiar, faster, confident, etc. Happy to talk more about this.

elements.text: Content lead for an SEO agency here. I’m probably an outlier, but here goes.

: ~30 — a mix of hired guns, on-demand writers, and a few we have on retainer-type contracts for ongoing work.

Short answer: We come up with the strategy based on target keywords/topics. We create, control, and execute the calendar. Writers don’t.

Our content team creates the editorial calendars. Based on keywords we want to target for our clients, we come up with X blogs/FAQs/other stuff per month. Usually plan out topics for 3-4 months max.

Beyond that, we start seeing how pages perform and sometimes refresh/update them. It’s a bit of a fool’s errand IMO to plan out more than that, unless we’ve identified topics that clients

they want to publish down the road. Like seasonal topics, for example. It varies.

As an SEO agency, we’re instant experts in all sorts of topics, but we usually have an SME on the client side to tap as needed. I try to align our freelance writers to the same clients so they’re more familiar, faster, confident, etc. Happy to talk more about this.

text: To add: For each topic, we write the content briefs in-house. Sometimes our writers have ad-hoc ideas and feedback upon assignment. I’m super flexible and open, so it their ideas have legs, I let them run with the topics in their writing.

elements.text: To add: For each topic, we write the content briefs in-house. Sometimes our writers have ad-hoc ideas and feedback upon assignment. I’m super flexible and open, so it their ideas have legs, I let them run with the topics in their writing.

text: At Animalz, it's totally dependent on Content Manager (i.e. writer) development level + tenure. With junior-level and newer CMs, Strategists (aka Team Leads) definitely take a more active role in setting the content calendar with the CM in a supporting role - but the more senior the CM, and the longer they've been with both the company and the account they're assigned to, the more the roles switch and the CM is expected to own the content calendar, with the strategist/team lead taking on more of a supportive/sounding board role.
